Posts.Title: finishing up radiation today!! dualgate paigelise

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2010 07:24PM paigelise wrote: scared...mine is 3 cms and very non-aggressive.  Get a notebook and start jotting down questions for when you see the Dr.  Get copies of your test results.  Like Roseann said don't get ahead of yourself.  your next step will probably be a biopsy.  Mine didn't hurt too bad at all.   You are in one of the worst phases now...the waiting around seems unbearable at times. I felt better once I knew exactly what I was dealing with and had a treatment plan. Please continue to post any questions here!  These ladies know everything! Wendy

Posts.Title: Results are cancer..please advise paigelise cookiegal

Posts.Content: Jul 30, 2010 06:19PM paigelise wrote: Hi...I am so sorry you are going thru so much!  The waiting is hard enough along with your family stuff.  It does sound though like you are finally with some decent doctors now.  Try to take it one step at a time.  Consider asking your Dr for an anti-anxiety medicine...I took some throughout my ordeal and it took the edge off.   Like CandDsMom said...80% of lumps are benign. Please continue to post any questions and vent here...the ladies here are a great support! Wendy
Posts.Title: Can't stop worrying :( Mommy2Katelynn Makratz

Posts.Content: paigelise wrote: My 2nd biopsy results came in (the first ones said fibrous) and the news is not good.  At this point all I know is I have "invasive ductal carcinoma insitu") and it is estrogen and progesten(?) positive.  It is well differentiated which the nurse said was good.  At this point I am seeing a surgeon Tuesday.  The nurse there thinks I will have a lumpectomy and radiation.  And start Tamoxifen because of the hormones.   I am in a dream (nightmare).  I go from laughing (don't know why) to crying.  It really hasn't hit me yet.  I feel like I am sliding down a dark tunnel and can't stop.  In one minute things are normal the next I'm like "I have CANCER".   I am 40 years old, no kids, no history in my family.  This is something that I never thought of.  Any suggestions on questions to ask the surgeon?  Books to read?   I dont' know where to start.  I don't know anyone that even has breast cancer.  It's always been something that someone's friend's relative has.   Please Advise. Thanks. Wendy Lumpectomy 11/6/09 Oncotype: 9 (No chemo!) BRCA: negative 33 Rads started 12/28/09 5 years Tamoxifen 3/1/10 Dx 10/20/2009, IDC, 3cm, Stage IIA, Grade 1, 0/2 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Results are cancer..please advise paigelise cookiegal

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2009 06:02PM paigelise wrote: Thank you all for your advice!  I went to the store and got some folders to keep track.  When the nurse was telling me what it was i wrote down "Invasive Ductal Insitu".  Now I see those are 2 different things.  I know for a fact it is invasive because she did describe how it is breaking out of the lining.  I am bringing my notebook and husband to the next appt on Tueday with the surgeon.  I am at this point trying not to let my mind run away to the "what ifs" and will focus on one appt at a time. I am also trying not to beat myself up on how I caused this.  Reading here I am amazed at all the different women with different stories and different backgrounds.  I will keep you updated.   Again...thank you for taking time out of your lives to support other women like you do.   I hope you all are feeling well. Wendy
Posts.Title: Results are cancer..please advise paigelise cookiegal

Posts.Content: May 26, 2010 08:39AM paigelise wrote: Mizress....80% of lumps are not cancerous.  However I would suggest getting it checked out by a mammogram or ultrasound....at least for your own peace of mind!  Check with your local clinic, hospital, gyn....I have heard of programs that do free or low cost mammograms for uninsured women.  Try not to let your mind race ahead...just take it a step at a time. Wendy
Posts.Title: FOUND A LUMP/KNOT...HELP! mizress mizress

Posts.Content: May 20, 2010 09:45AM paigelise wrote: Hi Army...I am so glad you found this web site...you are not alone...the women here are a wonderful support system!  First of all...most of the women here will tell you waiting for tests and not knowing what you are dealing with  is the most stressful part of all this.  You are NOT a whiner...you already have a lot of things going on in your life and sometimes it feels overwhelming.  I know how your mind can race ahead...don't automatically jump to needing a cancer specialist.  Take it one step at a time. First of all...you should demand to see another Dr and get a mammogram!  Start a notebook of people you talk to and keep going up the "food chain" until you get results.  If you can't get it at the base is there a women's clinic in the area you could go to?  I am not familiar with Army hosptials or Japan at all.  Keep posting on here and let us know what is going on!  80% of lumps are NOT cancer however a Dr would not be able to diagnosis that just by an exam.  So for your peace of mind do what you can to get the appropriate tests!  I found comfort in the beginning reading posts and the stories here.  Women get thru this...you will get thru this!  Wendy
Posts.Title: So scared I'm shaking. . . . Army-Travler lookingforward4more

Posts.Content: May 28, 2010 07:53PM paigelise wrote: Sas...these are great ideas!  The BC center had given me a planner from Cancer 101....I carried that with me everywhere!  And the tests....I loved all my Drs...but they still would miss forwarding on an occasional test result.

Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2009 01:08PM paigelise wrote: My insurance paid for a baseline mammogram when I was 35 - it was normal I was due for another mamm. when I turned 40 in April....I hadn't scheduled it yet but felt a lump in September so had the mamm and an ultrasound....it's IDC Stage IIA.    By the way....I (and my Drs) could not feel my lump unless I was standing up.  When I layed down for a typical self exam it would blend in and noone could feel it. Wendy

Posts.Content: Nov 21, 2009 02:09AM paigelise wrote: Hi Peppi....I'm sorry I don't know what those terms mean.  But I think it's good that even if it's benign you are getting that lump out.  I had a lumpectomy on 11/6 and it really wasn't too bad.  Let us know what happens!  Wendy
Posts.Title: Need a 2nd biopsy now Peppi1 Peppi1

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2010 05:49AM paigelise wrote: Dawn...everyone here can relate to how you are feeling!  I remember feeling "normal" and then remembering what I was dealing with and bursting into tears.  I also had this horrible feeling of being suffocated.  Take it one step at a time.  Keep coming to these boards but don't drive yourself crazy by automatically reading about chemo and surgery.  80% of lumps are benign.  The mammograms and scans these days pick up every little change so it could be any number of things. Take it easy on yourself...keep coming here to vent and ask questions! Wendy
Posts.Title: Feeling extremely down today bluesgrl staystrong

Posts.Content: Jun 24, 2010 05:21PM paigelise wrote: Kira...the SNB with the dye was not as bad for me as it sounds.  I think they put 5 injections in...I didn't feel 3 of them and the other 2 were a little pinch.  The lady Dr. who did the procedure put it in perspective for me...she said before the SNB procedure they would just take out a bunch of lymph nodes during the lumpectomy that could cause problems down the road.  I tried to look at it as "isn't this a cool technological procedure" and enjoyed my IV Valium! Wendy
Posts.Title: lots of fear kira1234 kira1234

Posts.Content: Jun 11, 2010 04:37PM paigelise wrote: Hi...sorry you are here but glad you found this board! I am really pro-second opinions however the ironic thing is that I never got one for my situation!  I also was very pleased with all my Drs. They were well experienced and very patient with me and my questions.  I would say go with your gut instinct.  You will have lots of decions along the way....this board was a great place for me to "research" and help make mine.  If along the way you DON"T feel comfortable with a Dr get a second opinion!  I also have 2A IDC and my treatment was lumpectomy, radiaiton and now on Tamoxifen.  Be sure to see if you are a candiate for the Oncotype test to see if chemo would benefit you. Wendy

Posts.Title: lymph node incision PeggyInPink NancyJP

Posts.Content: Oct 25, 2009 09:48PM paigelise wrote: Hi Renee...I was just learned my diagnosis over the phone on 10/23.  All i know is it is IDC and hormone postive.  They said it was "well differentiated" meaning it's a slow grower although it wasn't on my mammogram 5 years ago at age 35.  I see the surgeon on Tuesday.   I also was a bit relieved to hear some news.  Maybe this is why I have been so tired lately.   I'm glad we both found this site!  I come here every day to read up on things and get prepared for my visit to the surgeon.  Wendy
Posts.Title: Just Diagnosed today!!! mimi1964 rreynolds1

Posts.Content: May 26, 2010 09:09PM paigelise wrote: Sandy..I'm so sorry you are going thru this but glad you found this board!  This is where I did all my research and found a lot of support!  Labs may be different but from my biopsy they were able to tell me the type (Invasive Ductal) and that I am hormone positive...meaning estrogen and progestin (sp?) feed my cancer and ultimately I am on a medicine to block the estrogen.  The staging comes later after they take out the lump and test the nodes. And also my final pathology report told my Her status (mine was negative) and the grade...how fast growing it is.  For your appointment tomorrow...try to bring someone with you and have them take notes.  Or bring a tape recorder.  I also found it helpful to get copies of all my tests, have a separate calendar with all my appointments on it.  Take it one step at a time.  You will have some decisions to make along the way of your treatment.  Go with your gut instincts and get 2nd opinions if needed.  The worst part of the journey for me was the beginning.  Once I knew what I was dealing with and had a treatment plan things got better.  I also took a low dose of anti-anxiety medicine (Ativan) which helped out. I know it seems overwhelming at times but take it one step at a time! Wendy
Posts.Title: More Questions sandy_2124 navygirl

Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2009 09:30AM paigelise wrote: HI Ant...I am sorry for what you are going thru and it must be very hard to be separated from her!  I am new to this myself but wanted to offer my opinion as for the other test.  I just had a 3 cm IDC removed on 11-6.  The surgery went smoothly and they don't think it has spread.  However they are sending my tumor off for a test called an "Oncotype" which will determine how likely it is to recur.  This will help make a decision on if I will need chemo or not.  Since it wasn't in my nodes I may just need radiation but they wanted to be sure.  They said this Oncotype test could take 2-3 weeks to come back so perhaps that is the test they are doing on your wife?   Best wishes to you and your wife! Wendy
Posts.Title: Some questions Ant61 concernedsis

Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2010 04:01PM paigelise wrote: elceboo - my situation was different than yours...I have stage 2 w/lumpectomy and no chemo so I pretty much knew I would get the radiation.  All I can tell you is that the radiation will "sanitize" that area to make sure it kills any rogue cancer cells around.  I had also tried for the Mammosite (too young) but ended up going 5 days a week for 6 weeks.  They were pretty efficeint...I would get in and out fast and go to work for 2nd shift.  My skin held up really well...just tanned and a bit "prickly" at times.  My main problem was fatigue.  I took off the last 2 weeks from work for it. Maybe get a 2nd opinion?  What are your chances for recurrance if you DON"t get the radiation?  Just keep researching it and reading on here to help you make your decision.  Good Luck! Wendy
Posts.Title: Decisions, decisions... elceboo LuvRVing

Posts.Content: May 27, 2010 11:40AM paigelise wrote: Tori...I am sorry you are going thru this.  So many of the things you wrote I could really relate to. 1.  Easier said than done but try not to let your mind get out of control and race ahead!  Take it one step at a time.  80% of lumps are NOT cancer, but if it is cancer there are so many different types of it and so many treatments out there.  When I first got my diagnosis my immediate thought was that I would be incapacitated by chemo and not be able to work.  Turns out I had a low oncotype, didn't need chemo, and missed very little work.  Even if I did need chemo after reading on here it looks like it is manageable. 2.  It is great you are doing research but don't get too far ahead yet.  Your next step if the biopsy...maybe research how they do it.  Don't jump ahead to how to get thru chemo. 3.  Do NOT blame yourself!  I did in the beginning.  I also as a child has a weird phobia of cancer.  I always thought breast cancer was mostly hereditary and when I read all the risk factors I was like Uh-Oh!  I am a chronic yo-yo dieter..mostly on the up side.  I took birth control pills forever.  I rarely exercise.  I drink alcohol.  I use clinical strenth deodorant.  Don't take vitamins.  But there are women on here that have never been overweight, run marathons, etc and still got it.  Don't beat yourself up!  None of us have the perfect lifestyle! 4.  Do your best to take it easy now.  This is the worst part of it.  Once I knew exactly what I had and what my treatment was I felt more confident.  Your emotions may feel overwhelming at times but that is normal.  Take the Valium if you need to...this is what it's for!  I took Ativan to help out and now I rarely ever use it. 5.  Start getting copies of your tests to keep in a folder.  Take notes when you talk to Drs at appointments and on the phone.  6.  You are not alone.  You will meet women from all over the world on here.  All ages.  Ask anything or just come on to vent! Let us know how you are doing!  I am also a dog mom of 2 dogs!  Wendy
Posts.Title: I'm just a mess... ToriGirl Lisa1962

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2009 07:11AM paigelise wrote: I am newer to this but wanted to give my input.  My surgeon did a core biopsy in the office and it came back negative.  He scheduled an ultrasound guided biopsy which is able to get in the middle of the tumor (mine was bigger though at 3 cm) and the 2nd biopsy did come back as cancer (he explained the first biopsy just skimmed the surface).  I would suggest getting a 2nd biopsy to be safe. As for already talking about scheduling a mastectomy that seems a bit rushed to me. Even with mine being 3 cms and invasive I was able to get a lumpectomy. I do think you should get a 2nd opinion.  You are doing the right thing by taking a step back and assessing the situation!  I sometimes feel like I was sucked into a whirlwind and I am constantly researching to try and stay on top of things. Good luck to both of you!  Let us know what happens! Wendy
